title: Monday, 29th January, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:03am

Ugh, what a bloody morning. Anyway! Hello, good morning, welcome, hi.

Soundbuy Morning all...............
VV75 morning
wayneJ Morning
Featherd Morning
Grouchmonkey Morning, morning
Manxish Morning

Life has become chaotic

PM11:04am

But thought I'd pop my head round

11:04 am
PM11:04am

AAAA bonjour !

Oh, hello Paul. Good of you to stop by. Quiet here. Nothing much to talk about.

Markkus morning
Maverick Couple interesting snippets. Telit Communications confirming potential bidders for Automotive Division
Peace and Love Guten Tag

Same your side of the office, I'm guessing.

11:04 am

I am so out of the loop

Maverick Good read with regards to TCM in The Times at the weekend
PM11:05am

But this Pres Club thing does now seem to have calmed down

Otter Hello internet friends
PM11:05am

I do feel guilty tho

wayneJ Morning PM - tell us have you had any dinner invites cancelled recently?

.... why?

yes, really

Murph, if you come across any more disgusting events like this Presidents Club dinner can you get two tickets for myself and Lenny?

OnYourRight Morning all
11:08 am

Deary me.

PM11:09am

The thing you are never able to share with stories like this is the avalanche of legal threats you get just prior to publication

J L Morning

Cos it's from lawyers we never print the stuff

Otter I would like to go and see the darts at the alexandra palace
11:09 am

let me share a snippet

Tom Dalgleish Isn't a legal threat newsworthy too?
Paper Chase The demise of the Presidents Club is a victory for apostrophes everywhere.
PM11:10am

The publication of such grave allegations would be highly defamatory of our client and
wholly without merit. To make the position strictly clear there is no substance
whatsoever in these allegations and to publish them you would put yourselves gravely
at risk.

TheManwithaLongChin Has BE been playing golf?
PM11:10am

We therefore put you
on notice that should you be foolish enough to publish these allegations you are likely
to expose yourselves to a substantial claim for financial loss.

11:10 am
PM11:10am

hmm

PM11:10am

Anyway, enough of that

11:10 am
BE11:10am

I'd reject it on that basis alone.

PM11:11am

Still chuckling tho about the VC from Bolton University

Flaneur Nice that they have your interest at heart, though (the lawyers).
PM11:11am

Had this nice little junket. First class travel down to London on expenses. his wife came too.

Shinshin @Pm would be an interesting article in itself tho, lifting the lid on the legal pressures. Could be done in an anonymised diary way "Mon - call subject for comment. Tue - receive writ from legal firm " etc
Tom Dalgleish London lawyers like their "wholly"'s
11:11 am
PM11:11am

Nice London hotel.

wayneJ If I had been present my letter to the FT would have been : 'Dear PM, thank you for bringing to my attention that my behavior was poor. This will clearly embarrass me but as a citizen I believe the freedom of the press (and the issue of objectification of women) is more important so please go ahead and publish. '
PM11:11am

She went shopping and met up with some friends.

PM11:11am

He landed himself in The Sun as a sleaze bag.

rw42 Would be a nice story to correlate the legal letters which people who subsequently turned out to have left early before all the shenanigans allegedly occurred!
11:11 am
PM11:11am

Suspect the train ride home was a bit uncomfortable.

But enough of that

undefined

...... Though there's very little happening corporate wise.

RA morning you crazy kids
11:13 am
BE11:13am

Sanofi's bought something.

BE11:14am

Ablynx, for $4.8bn. Having bought Bioverativ last week, for $11.6bn.

Electric Dragon nothing wrong with split infinitives
Electric Dragon and that isn't one anyway
BE11:15am

And outbids a $2.6bn offer from Novo. Why's Sanofi buying all this stuff?

11:15 am
PM11:15am

Wot?

BE11:16am

And why's it paying, in this case, c6.5x 2022 sales for a bolt-on?

PM11:16am

They paid almost twice offered by Novo??

11:16 am
BE11:17am

Yep. Sanofi €45 per share offer. Novo Nordisk offered €30.5 per share.

STXMLD2 Time to sell SAN FR?
PM11:17am

Alright, not twice, but 50% boost

BE11:17am

This is rare disease price gouging stuff ..... In this case, acquired thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura.

11:17 am
PM11:18am

Which sounds nasty

BE11:18am

Yes, I cut and pasted that.

BE11:18am

Here's Berenberg.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

While this deal is likely slightly earnings dilutive in the near term, if we assume that
caplacizumab can approach €400m in sales by 2023 at a 60% or higher margin, then this
could be 1.5% EPS accretive by then. However, we calculate this would generate no more
than a 4% return on invested capital by that time frame.
● Added to Bioverativ, these two transactions will total more than €13bn in invested capital
and by 2023 combined returns would be about 5% by our calculations. Although these deals
combined could be high single-digit accretive to earnings by 2023, they look expensive on
returns.

OnYourRight You've got to love a bit of Private Eye...... hahaha
PM11:18am

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is a rare blood disorder. In TTP, blood clots form in small blood vessels throughout the body. The clots can limit or block the flow of oxygen-rich blood to the body's organs, such as the brain, kidneys, and heart.

BE11:19am

Yeah, that's the one.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Have some Citi as well.

hornblower any comment on conviviality, -12%, as synergies pushed back to next year
RA I have high hopes for siemens this year but would be happy to know if anyone else shared this view?
tadam So now you are writing about Ablynx? After the event.
BE11:19am

While the market may query the valuation, the strategic rationale is clear and the move needs to be considered in context with the recent moves Sanofi has made. Ablynx gives Sanofi a nanobody drug discovery platform, product and
pipeline to strengthen its hematology franchise build efforts. This move follows full development/commercialisation rights being gained for fitusiran (RNAi for Hemophilia A/B patients with or without inhibitors), and the acquisition of BIVV that provides infrastructure in hemophilia, an established extended half-life factor VIII/IX
replacement franchise and rare bleeding disorder pipeline. Sanofi will launch a public tender offer in Q2 and requires greater than 75% to complete the deal. While Novo has yet to comment we do not believe it will launch a counter offer, given efforts to engage with the Ablynx board to date have been unsuccessful.

BE11:20am

Novo has now commented, by the way, and said: "yours!"

11:20 am
BE11:20am

(@tadam: why are you commenting on things we've already written? After the event.)

BE11:21am

They're neutral Sanofi .....

PM11:21am

Yeah, do watch your lip tadam

11:21 am
BE11:21am

We see an inflection in EPS growth coming from
2019e, reflecting the REGN collaboration turning profitable and diabetes headwinds abating. That said, recent downgrades across the rest of the business leave us below 2018-20e consensus and we do not see upcoming ODYSSEY outcomes data for Praluent as a significant catalyst (bar set very high for trial to surprise positively). Preferred pharma plays remain AZN, BAYgN, BMY, LLY.

BE11:22am

The wider picture here is haemo, of course.

BE11:22am

ICER's draft report on Hemlibra was out over the weekend: https://icer-revie..._Report_012618.pdf

11:22 am

BE11:24am

(@Alewis: Indeed! I realised that after typing. I offer my sincere apologies to [redacted lawyer firm] for any distress caused and hope they accept my generous settlement offer.)

11:24 am
BE11:25am

Rather than waffle on about haemo A and B markets myself, here's Citi to waffle on about haemo A and B.

BE11:26am

We forecast HEMLIBRA sales in 2020/25/30e of $1.6/3.4/3.8bn (3-5% of group sales for Roche) versus 2020 consensus of $1.3bn. Shire’s Hematology franchise in 2017 is expected to post
sales of $3.7bn (greater than 50% ex-US), of which FEIBA for inhibitor patients represents
$800m and Advate/Adynovate greater than $2.5bn. Our base case assumption is for franchise
erosion with 2020/25 sales of $3.1/2.4bn (19/13% of group), with FEIBA declining
greater than 50% to $0.3bn. This implies a 2017-22 erosion rate of –6% versus consensus at – 5%. We argue the current share price is discounting an overly bearish erosion rate of -15% per annum for Shire’s Hematology franchise. For Sanofi, we forecast 2025/30e risk adjusted sales for Ph III asset fitusiran (RNAi treatment of Hem A/B in patients with and without inhibitors) of $0.8/1.2bn, and note consensus expectations
for BIVV’s hemophilia franchise are $1.2/1.6bn in 2017/20 (3-4% of Sanofi’s group sales). Bayer’s current hemophilia franchise is expected to post declining sales – 17% to $1.1bn in 2017, reflecting the ongoing contract dispute with partner CSL as well as competitive dynamics. We forecast Kogenate/Kovaltry and Bayer’s Iblias (long acting FVIII) to generate 2025/30e sales of $1.3/1.2bn (c.2% of Bayer group sales or on a pro forma bias including Monsanto). Novo’s NovoSeven ($1.4bn sales in FY17m, 8% of group) does not have a prophylaxis indication in the US with approximately 50% of sales coming from indications outside of Hemophilia A. We assume erosion with 2020/25 sales of $1.0/0.7bn (2-5% of group), and broader Hemophilia 2017/20/25 franchise sales of $1.6/1.3/1bn (9/6/4% of group).

Shire PLC (SHP:LSE): Last: 3,454, up 15 (+0.44%), High: 3,483, Low: 3,444, Volume: 715.52k

11:32 am
PM11:32am

We visited GKN’s UK Driveline facility in Birmingham today and heard an update on: new guidance, the pension, future reporting, future strategy, and eDrive hidden value.

wayneJ (Congrats to Izy)
PM11:32am

Why are they showing people round the Driveline facility when their in the middle of a hostile bid?

PM11:33am

Management is expecting to announce targets in relation to the Project Boost initiative in the next few weeks with these targets currently being audited by the group’s accountants. We think this is key to helping investors judge whether they are better off with the Melrose offer (and a 57% share of its targeted improvements) or with current management.

11:33 am
PM11:33am

The company maintains that the UK actuarial pension deficit (i.e. the one from the triennial review which sets pension contributions) is ~£400m. They note that the £1.1bn recently quoted by pension trustees was highlighting what the deficit could be if a more cautious 'gilts flat' discount rate was applied due to a change in ownership/capital structure impacting the perceived risk profile of the scheme. GKN claim the higher gilts + 1.75% discount rate they are able to apply is due to their strong relationship with pension trustees.

PM11:33am

Think that's the offending par

PM11:33am

There's obviously been a row at the Panel over that note

11:33 am
PM11:34am

Hang, just reading that myself

PM11:34am

GKN claim the higher gilts + 1.75% discount rate they are able to apply is due to their strong relationship with pension trustees.

PM11:34am

What's this 'strong relationship' stuff

11:35 am
PM11:35am

It kinda implies the pension trustees do what GKN management asks

PM11:35am

Anyway, pensions too complicated for me.

PM11:35am

Lets move on

11:35 am
BE11:36am

Hm. I've never totally understood why the Panel goes into overdrive to force clarification on all statements relating to a public bid. It does rather contrast the underdrive they approach a non-public bid.

BE11:36am

Before we do move on though .....

PM11:36am

this is true

11:36 am
BE11:36am

.... interesting thing from Sandy Morris at Jefferies, questioning whether GKN can be turned around in a rush by anyone.

BE11:37am

Melrose states the optimal time to sell is 3 to 5 years, but it's flexible. We believe 5 years is not long in Aerospace and not long enough to capture maximum value for GKN Aerospace. In Automotive, we believe profound change will be driven by Hybrids and EVs, something that again cannot be accommodated within 5 years. In both markets, we regard stability as desirable and would prefer clarity as to tenure of ownership. Further, if Melrose owns GKN for 5 years, would it not start to morph into GKN? In short, Melrose offers a simple initial part solution to GKN shareholders, but it may then get more complex.

Bonnemort I remember the fate of a GKN subsidiary which was spun off (UEF Garringtons), didn't end well for pensioners.
BE11:37am

In 2017, Airbus and Boeing enjoyed material share price performance. It took, however, a long time for the penny to drop and reveal the future returns from a decade of investment, but when it did the focus shifted to FY20, even beyond. We believe the same can happen at GKN Aerospace. In Auto, we see Driveline and Powder Metallurgy as a powerful combination as the industry shifts to Hybrids - and GKN has told us of the £2bn eDrive backlog - and EVs.

Tom Dalgleish Regarding Defenx isnt it terrible when Wikipedia doesnt cover it
11:37 am
BE11:37am

Beaten into submission. If we increase the FY21-FY30 Group margin assumption in our DCF from a mediocre 8% to a plausible-looking 10%, our valuation leaps by 21% from 426p to 515p. It's the effect of a low base. Then, improved FCF should impact positively on capital turnover - from 3.0x, each 0.1 adds around 17p. So, we don't think Melrose's financial terms are compelling, we do not see it as certainly a better owner of GKN's businesses, but we hesitate to say Melrose is the wrong solution. GKN's FY17 results may be the clincher, one way or another.

wayneJ Would make sense that a more levered capital structure should require a lower discount rate for the pensions (ie higher risk of default)
GKN PLC (GKN:LSE): Last: 434.80, down 1.2 (-0.28%), High: 438.10, Low: 432.40, Volume: 1.38m

Conviviality PLC (CVR:LSE): Last: 295.00, down 63 (-17.60%), High: 357.00, Low: 295.00, Volume: 1.67m
BE12:10pm

Gross margin hit in the current year, earnings pushed out to the second.

BE12:10pm

WH Ireland.

12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

Conviviality has this morning released interim results to 29 October 2017, illustrating a period of continued progress and positive trading momentum. Each of the three divisions performed well, demonstrating customers’ confidence in the enlarged proposition, with the Group securing some notable long-term contracts with both existing and new customers. Trading since the end of the period has also been positive with sales in the first 9 weeks ahead by +8.4% and as previously indicated, cost savings are expected to fully come through in H2 2018E and beyond. Also of note since the period end was the acquisition of the 127 Central Convenience stores. On the back of the results, we leave our 2-year earnings forecasts unchanged. Reflecting the growth outlook and a step change in the year-end working capital profile, we have increased our FY 2018E net debt expectation to £150.1m, whilst our average debt and interest forecasts are unchanged. The shares have moved c.10% lower since the beginning of the year and now trade on a PER multiple of 15.4x falling to 13.6x, backed by an attractive 3.8% dividend yield. We see fair value for the shares at 470p.​

BE12:11pm

Continuation of H1’s strength through November & December and confirmation
of landing cost saving initiatives in H2 help underpin FY expectations. This
should reassure, in our view, given recent share price weakness. We view
Conviviality as a multi-year growth story that can deliver market share gains
through its nationwide scale and “one-stop shop” model. Valuation (14x CY18E
PE) undemanding, in our view, with risk/reward to the upside.
 1H18 results – strong trading performance, well set to meet expectations:
Group Sales +9.2% (Retail +10%, Trading +9.6% & Direct +6.9%). As expected
gross margins fell 30bps, reflecting a shift mix towards national accounts; adjusted
EBITDA £23.3m +1.7%, PBT £15.1m -2% (higher D&A), EPS 6.8p -4.4% and
DPS 4.5p +7%.
 Trading demonstrates market share gains in our view, with Direct particularly
pleasing in our view. Growth continues to be driven through new outlet wins and
increased sales / outlet as customers continue to embrace Conviviality’s “one-stop
shop” approach, evidenced by new long-term supply agreements with some of its
largest customers (Stonegate Pub Company & JD Wetherspoon).

12:11 pm
BE12:11pm

 Integration of key group projects now largely complete, e.g. bringing Matthew
Clark and Bibendum onto the same ERP system. As previously announced, this
and other integration projects now allow for practices across business units to be
brought into individual group functions, e.g. buying, marketing & operations.
 Current trading healthy – group sales +8.4% for Nov & Dec with Direct +7.7%.
Management remains confident of meeting expectations with cost initiatives on
track, having been deferred into H2. Continued momentum & annualisation of cost
savings could offer upside in outer years. We leave forecasts largely unchanged,
but expect FY18E net debt of £147m (was £102m) due to working capital changes.
 Valuation (14x CY18E PE) undemanding in our view with further upside, in our
view, in the context of strong top-line performance, execution of integration
activities with upside risk to outer year forecasts.

12:12 pm
BE12:12pm

The trading update issued by the company in November highlighted a strong trading performance across each of the three divisions and provided the divisional revenue performances which were ahead of our expectations. The statement also highlighted that the winning of some large customer accounts was going to have an adverse impact on the gross margin and also that due to the high levels of growth the phasing of some synergies would be more H2 weighted as a result of investing to maintaining service levels. Therefore, the focus in the interims results for us is profitability and bridging it to full year expectations. We are also keen to see how recent trading has been progressing given the challenging retail backdrop and also more detail around the reshaping of the leadership team that has resulted in the departures to some seemingly key personnel. Finally, there may be updates in relation to the recent acquisition of WS Retail on 15 December 2017
